notes:
1. Power in Three-Phase Systems

The total power in a balanced three-phase system is the sum of the power in each of the three phases. The advantage of three-phase power is that the total instantaneous power is constant, which results in smoother operation for large motors.

2. Total Power Formulas

The formulas for total active power ($P$), reactive power ($Q$), and apparent power ($S$) in a balanced three-phase system are given in terms of line quantities ($V_L, I_L$). These formulas work for both Wye and Delta connected loads.

  • Total Active Power (P): The real power consumed by the load, measured in Watts (W).
    • $$ P = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \cos(\phi) $$
  • Total Reactive Power (Q): The power that oscillates between the source and the load, measured in Volt-Amps Reactive (VAR).
    • $$ Q = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \sin(\phi) $$
  • Total Apparent Power (S): The vector sum of active and reactive power, measured in Volt-Amps (VA).
    • $$ S = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L = \sqrt{P^2 + Q^2} $$

In these formulas, $\phi$ is the phase angle of the load impedance, and $\cos(\phi)$ is the power factor (PF).

solvedExamples.question: A balanced three-phase load is connected to a 480 V line. It draws a line current of 20 A at a power factor of 0.8 lagging. What is the total active power consumed by the load?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula for total active power: $P = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L \cos(\phi)$.
$P = \sqrt{3} (480 \text{ V})(20 \text{ A})(0.8) \approx (1.732)(480)(20)(0.8) \approx 13302$ W, or 13.3 kW.

solvedExamples.question: For the load in the previous problem, what is the total apparent power?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the formula for total apparent power: $S = \sqrt{3} V_L I_L$.
$S = \sqrt{3} (480 \text{ V})(20 \text{ A}) \approx (1.732)(480)(20) \approx 16627$ VA, or 16.6 kVA. Alternatively, $S = P / PF = 13.3 \text{ kW} / 0.8 = 16.625$ kVA.
